To my friends and countrymen!

Urged from many sides to write down the memories of my life, as well as the events of the year ’48, insofar as they touched me personally, and to publish these recollections, I will hereby fulfill my friends’ wish. I ask only for your kind indulgence if my descriptions are not elegant. Well then, I will do the best I can.

Once upon a time, many, many years ago, in the old city of Zerbst, in the beautiful land of Anhalt in Germany, a sturdy boy was born to an honest draper and his wife. This boy was later baptized in the Reformed church and given the name August. Now, I cannot honestly remember all the details; only this much was clear to me—that I must be August. The boy grew up; he loved his food and drink, and when, in his youthful ways, he got up to some silly pranks, he often received quite sensible reminders from his father or his mother.

When I was six, I was sent to a so‑called “Winkel school” (a small private “corner school”) run by an old cantor’s widow named Dürre and assisted by her already rather grown daughter, Auguste. Later, when the city council of Zerbst had a large, stately building erected and designated it as a public school, all school-age children from five to fourteen were required to attend it, and the Winkel school ceased operation. At the entrance examination, I received a report card: admitted to the first class on a trial basis. I attended for the next five years, and in the last two I was the top student.

In 1844 I was confirmed, and now it was time to choose a profession for life. I would have loved to become a fur tanner, but I could not find a master to teach me. In 1842 I had begun an apprenticeship with my mother’s brother, who was a master fur tanner, and I worked at his place in my spare time when I was not in school. But before I could be confirmed, he died, and since I could not find another master, although I tried very hard, I began my apprenticeship with Franz Wiegand, the best cabinetmaker around. The apprenticeship lasted four years. On 8 June 1848, after passing my examination, I was declared a journeyman carpenter, and the court assessor in office took my word and my handshake and charged me to travel to foreign parts, to see other cities and countries, so that, when the time came, I could become a capable master of the trade and a good citizen. That I have honestly done. Before I tell of it, though, I would first like to speak a bit about the beautiful land of Anhalt and then about the events of the year ’48.

The forester was a very friendly and entertaining man, and each evening, when he was at home, all the people who lived in the house and in the neighborhood gathered outside.

Mr. Forester sat in the middle, and everyone listened attentively. Then he began: “Now I have to tell you a story—you have probably never heard one like it in your entire life—the story of the poisonous tree on the island of Celebes.” And he elaborated at length on the terrible consequences of this tree’s fumes. Birds fell dead from the air; wild animals that roamed near the tree collapsed; and people who, out of ignorance, dared to approach it also died. Over the course of many years, so many bodies had accumulated near the tree that the poisonous stench from their decomposition made it impossible for any living creature to remain on the island. And as long as we were there, he told this same story every evening as if it were news, and everybody listened with suspense as if they had never heard it before, exclamations of amazement and surprise ringing out loudly.
